messages.content:
You are an AI assistant specialized in analyzing web projects developed using PHP and the Laravel framework. I need to generate an OpenAPI Specification for a web project based on its backend source code. I'm now focusing on endpoint `/api/v1/posts` with method POST, and here is the relevant information I found:

1. In `app/Http/Controllers/Api/V1/PostController.php`, `App\\Http\\Controllers\\Api\\V1\\PostController::store` is implemented to process HTTP requests to `/api/v1/posts` with HTTP method POST.

I'll provide you with the contents of the files mentioned above, you have the option to execute additional Unix commands to gather more information if necessary, but you must not run the source code of the project, and your task is to generate a list of Parameter Objects (the value of paths.[endpoint].[method].parameters) in Swagger 2.0 format.

You need to think step by step and provide an explanation of your results first. Then, output exactly "the final generated result begins" (I will split your output and then do json parse, so you must output it and do not change it), followed by the list of Parameter Objects in JSON format. Do not include fields not mentioned above, and do not use references ($ref) in your output (try to obtain the structure by executing additional Unix commands).

Okay, I need to determine the parameters for the `POST /api/v1/posts` endpoint based on the provided code. The `store` method in `PostController` handles the POST request. It uses `PostsRequest` to validate the incoming data. I need to examine the `PostsRequest` class to understand the expected input parameters.

I will use the `run_command` to inspect the `PostsRequest` class.

function.name: run_command
function.description: Run a Unix command and get outputs in the project directory. You must not run any source code of the project.

message.content:
The `PostsRequest` class defines the validation rules. Based on the `rules()` method, the following parameters are expected in the request body:

*   `title`: required, string
*   `content`: required, string
*   `posted_at`: required, date
*   `thumbnail_id`: nullable, exists in `media` table, integer
*   `author_id`: required, exists in `users` table, integer

Now I can generate the Parameter Objects.

the final generated result begins
```json
[
  {
    "name": "title",
    "in": "body",
    "description": "Title of the post",
    "required": true,
    "type": "string"
  },
  {
    "name": "content",
    "in": "body",
    "description": "Content of the post",
    "required": true,
    "type": "string"
  },
  {
    "name": "posted_at",
    "in": "body",
    "description": "Date when the post was published",
    "required": true,
    "type": "string",
    "format": "date"
  },
  {
    "name": "thumbnail_id",
    "in": "body",
    "description": "ID of the thumbnail image",
    "required": false,
    "type": "integer"
  },
  {
    "name": "author_id",
    "in": "body",
    "description": "ID of the author",
    "required": true,
    "type": "integer"
  }
]
```
